Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German ezzen, from Old High German ezzan, from Proto-Germanic *etanÄ…, from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚ed-. Cognate with Low German eten, Dutch eten, English eat, Danish Ã¦de, Norwegian ete, Swedish Ã¤ta, Yiddish ×¢×¡×Ÿ‎ (esn) and Gothic ğŒ¹ğ„ğŒ°ğŒ½ (itan). Non-Germanic cognates include Latin edÅ, Russian ĞµÑÑ‚ÑŒ (jestÊ¹), Scottish Gaelic ith.

Verb[edit]

essen (class 5 strong, third-person singular simple present isst, past tense aÃŸ, past participle gegessen, past subjunctive Ã¤ÃŸe, auxiliary haben)

  1. (transitive) to eat
    Er isst gern Schokolade.
    He likes eating chocolate.
    Ich esse einen Apfel.
    I am eating an apple.
  2. (intransitive) to eat; to dine
    Wir haben noch nicht gegessen.
    We have not eaten yet.
    Sie haben immer vor 9 Uhr abends gegessen.
    They always ate before 9 oâ€™clock in the evening.

Usage notes[edit]

  • In obsolete usage, the past participle was frequently gessen, which is still used in Austria.
